Introduction

Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a disruption in brain function caused by an external force, and severity can vary widely.  A mild TBI (concussion) is a transient impairment in neurologic function without a structural intracranial injury.  Symptoms may include headache, nausea, dizziness, confusion, and/or changes in attention or emotion.  Moderate to severe TBI typically involves serious intracranial injuries (eg, intraparenchymal hemorrhage), which lead to depressed mental status, significant neurologic deficits, and an increased risk for permanent disability or death.

Pathogenesis



TBI results from a mechanical force exerted on the brain.  Common etiologies include blunt force or penetrating trauma to the head, or acceleration-deceleration injuries, which occur when the brain shifts rapidly against the skull (eg, due to blast/explosion exposure, severe whiplash) (

figure 1
).  Injuries to the brain occur by 2 main mechanisms:



  • Primary injury:  Occurs at the time of injury from the force of impact and involves direct damage to brain structures.  Primary injuries include cerebral contusions, hemorrhages, and axonal injury (shearing of the long white matter tracts of the brain) (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Secondary injury:  Develops hours to days after the initial trauma due to a cascade of biochemical inflammatory reactions.  The release of excitatory neurotransmitters (eg, glutamate), generation of free radicals with oxidative stress, disruption of the blood-brain barrier, and microvascular ischemia contribute to neuronal cell death and worsen neurologic outcomes.

TBI classification

Mild TBI



Mild TBI, which is synonymous with concussion, is defined as a posttraumatic disturbance in neurologic function without a structural intracranial injury.  TBIs are classified as mild when the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
) score, calculated at least 30 minutes after the injury, is between 13 and 15 (although some evidence suggests a GCS score of 14-15 may be more appropriate).

Moderate and severe TBI



Moderate TBI is defined by a postinjury GCS score of 9-12, and severe TBI is defined by a postinjury GCS score of 3-8.  Moderate and severe TBIs typically involve structural injuries, which may include:



  • Skull fractures (eg, basilar skull fracture).
  • Cerebral contusions and intraparenchymal hemorrhages.
  • Intracranial hemorrhages (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ) (eg, epidural hematoma, subdural hematoma, subarachnoid hemorrhage).
  • Diffuse axonal injury (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ):  Shearing forces break the axonal cytoskeleton, leading to impairment of axonal transport, swelling, and potential degeneration of the axon.
  • Cerebral edema, increased intracranial pressure (ICP), and brain herniation (
    figure 3
    ).

Risk factors



Risk factors for TBI include:



  • Motor vehicle collisions.
  • Falls (particularly in elderly and pediatric populations).
  • Sports-related injuries (eg, football, rugby).
  • Assaults and physical violence.
  • Blast injuries (eg, military personnel).


The following factors increase the risk for moderate to severe TBI:



  • Anticoagulant use/history of coagulopathy.
  • Advanced age (â‰¥65).
  • High-energy mechanism of injury (eg, ejection from vehicle, fall from height).
  • Alcohol and substance use.

Clinical presentation

Mild TBI (concussion)



Concussion symptoms that develop at the time of head injury or within several minutes to hours include:



  • Transient loss of consciousness for â‰¤30 minutes (may be absent).
  • Headache, dizziness/balance issues (eg, stumbling gait), and/or disorientation (eg, unsure of surroundings or date).
  • Nausea and vomiting.
  • Amnesia (retrograde or anterograde):  Patients often lack memory of the trauma and the events immediately preceding or following the injury.


Concussion symptoms that may develop over hours to days after the head injury include:



  • Cognitive impairment (eg, confusion, difficulty concentrating).
  • Emotional lability (eg, irritability, tearfulness).
  • Speech changes (eg, slurring, incoherence).
  • Sleep disturbances (eg, insomnia, excessive daytime sleepiness).
  • Headaches triggered by physical or cognitive exertion or visual tasks (eg, rapid eye movement between 2 points).
  • Light and/or noise sensitivity (exposure may worsen ongoing headaches).

Moderate to severe TBI



Clinical features of a moderate to severe TBI include:



  • Prolonged loss of consciousness (>30 min for moderate TBI, >24 hr for severe TBI).
  • Seizures and persistent neurologic deficits (eg, focal weakness, aphasia, visual changes).
  • Depressed or declining mental status (eg, increasing somnolence).
  • Depressed skull fracture or signs of basilar skull fracture (eg, Battle sign, hemotympanum) (
    figure 4
    ).
  • Increased ICP:  Severe headache, persistent vomiting, altered mental status, and/or Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, agonal respirations) (
    figure 5
    ).
  • Absent brainstem reflexes (eg, no cough, gag, or corneal reflex).
  • Decorticate or decerebrate posturing (
    figure 6
    ).
  • Brain death (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ).

Diagnosis



TBI represents a spectrum of disease with variable clinical presentations.  A thorough history and physical examination are essential to determine whether a head injury is likely to be mild, moderate, or severe.  Important factors to consider include the type/severity of head trauma (eg, motor vehicle collision, penetrating injury), patient's comorbidities (eg, advanced age, anticoagulant use), initial GCS score, and severity of neurologic symptoms (eg, disorientation, coma).

Mild TBI (concussion)



Concussion is primarily a clinical diagnosis characterized by a GCS score of 13-15 and mild neurocognitive symptoms (eg, headache, confusion) without focal neurologic deficits.  Standardized tools, such as the Sport Concussion Assessment Tool (SCAT), can help evaluate for concussion after a minor head injury (particularly at sporting events), but they do not replace a comprehensive medical evaluation.



Neuroimaging (eg, CT scan of the head) is not required for the diagnosis of concussion but should be obtained to rule out structural injury in patients with high-risk features (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).  Decision rules can help identify individuals at risk for significant intracranial injuries while avoiding unnecessary radiation exposure.  Urgent noncontrast CT scan of the head is indicated if any of the following criteria are present:



  • Age â‰¥65, history of coagulopathy (eg, hemophilia) or anticoagulant use, acute intoxication, high-risk mechanism of injury (eg, ejection from a vehicle).
  • Severe headache, â‰¥2 episodes of vomiting, seizure, retrograde amnesia â‰¥30 minutes prior to trauma, focal neurologic deficit.
  • Evidence of depressed or basilar skull fracture, altered mental status, abnormal behavior (eg, excessive agitation), GCS score <15 at 2 hours after injury.


Patients with a mild TBI and no high-risk criteria have a low likelihood of clinically significant intracranial injury, and imaging can often be deferred.  These patients should be closely monitored by a reliable caregiver for at least 24 hours, and, if they develop any worsening symptoms (eg, severe headache, increased somnolence, seizures), they must return for reevaluation and CT imaging.



Patients with a mild TBI and a normal CT scan can generally be discharged home with close observation.  However, patients with severe or concerning symptoms (eg, repeated vomiting, anticoagulant use, GCS score persistently <15) should be admitted to the hospital for observation (

figure 7
).

Pediatric considerations



The Pediatric Emergency Care Applied Research Network (PECARN) TBI rules are clinically validated to determine which children (age <18) with mild TBI require CT imaging (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
).  Observation in the emergency department (eg, 4-6 hr) may be considered as an alternative to CT scan if the child has normal mental status, no signs of basilar skull fracture, and improvement in other high-risk features (eg, resolved vomiting).  Children classified as low risk for significant TBI per the PECARN rule can be safely discharged home without imaging or emergency department observation.

Moderate to severe TBI



Moderate to severe TBI (eg, GCS score 3-12) is stabilized as needed (eg, intubation, cervical spine immobilization) before the patient undergoes evaluation with an urgent noncontrast CT scan of the head.  CT scan rapidly and reliably identifies serious injuries such as brain hemorrhage, cerebral edema, and midline shift (eg, shifting of the brain due to mass effect from a hematoma).  Patients with abnormalities on CT scan require inpatient admission and neurosurgical evaluation.  If initial imaging is negative, patients with moderate to severe TBI are typically admitted to the hospital and monitored (eg, frequent neurologic checks) for signs of neurologic decompensation.

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory testing is not indicated to diagnose TBI but is often obtained as part of a broader trauma evaluation (eg, complete blood count, type and screen, renal function).

Imaging studies



CT scan of the head without IV contrast is the initial test in moderate to severe TBI or mild TBI with high-risk features.  CT scan rapidly identifies conditions that may require neurosurgical intervention, including skull fractures, hemorrhages, cerebral edema, and midline shift (

image 1
).



MRI of the brain is more sensitive than CT scan for detecting small hematomas and axonal injuries (

image 2
).  However, MRI is time-consuming, more expensive, and typically reserved for cases in which CT is negative but clinical concern for intracranial injury persists.

Management

Mild TBI (concussion)



Concussions are managed in the outpatient setting (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 7
).  Interventions include:



  • Symptom control:  Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications for headache, antiemetics for nausea.
  • Cognitive and physical rest for 24-48 hours:  Avoidance of excessive screen time, prolonged reading/studying, or any activity that requires significant attention or focus.  A brief (1- or 2-day) absence from school/work is often recommended.
  • Gradual return-to-activity protocol:  Gradually increased intensity of physical activity (eg, light exercise â†’ noncontact sport â†’ competitive play) over a minimum of 5 days.  Patients should remain symptom-free before progressing to the next level.  Most patients resume normal activities within a month.
  • Patients with multiple concussions may be advised to discontinue contact sports, particularly if progressively less force results in symptoms and/or recovery takes longer with each episode.

Moderate to severe TBI



Moderate to severe TBIs, particularly in patients with CT scan abnormalities (eg, hemorrhage), typically require neurosurgical consultation/intervention and admission to the intensive care unit.  Depending on the extent of the injury, stabilizing interventions to minimize primary and secondary brain injuries may include (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 8
):



  • Intubation to secure the airway (in patients with obtundation) and/or ensure adequate ventilation and oxygenation (goal SpO2 >90%).
  • Fluids and/or vasopressors to maintain adequate mean arterial pressure (MAP), which thereby improves cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) (ie, CPP = MAP â€“ ICP).
  • ICP reduction (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 9
    ):
    • Head elevation:  Increases venous outflow from the brain.
    • Osmotic therapy (eg, hypertonic saline, mannitol):  Decreases cerebral edema by creating an osmolar gradient that draws water out of edematous brain tissue.
    • Sedation (eg, propofol, midazolam):  Decreases cerebral metabolic demand and cerebral blood volume.
    • Hyperventilation:  Induces vasoconstriction and reduces cerebral blood flow by decreasing PaCO2 but must be done cautiously to avoid ischemia.
  • Neurosurgical intervention:  Involves decompressive craniectomy, hematoma evacuation, and dural closure (if penetrating injury).
  • Anticoagulation reversal (eg, vitamin K for warfarin):  Minimizes bleeding.
  • Seizure prophylaxis (eg, levetiracetam):  Prevents seizure-induced increase in metabolic demand and further increased ICP.
  • Maintain normoglycemia and normothermia to minimize metabolic demand.

Postconcussion syndrome



Postconcussion syndrome (PCS) is a complex disorder in which concussion symptoms persist for >4 weeks following a mild TBI (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 10
).  Risk factors for PCS include a history of multiple concussions or nonadherence to gradual return-to-play protocols.



PCS is a clinical diagnosis based on symptoms (eg, headache, dizziness, cognitive impairment, unstable moods) that persist beyond the expected recovery period, with exclusion of other potential causes (eg, psychiatric disorders, mass).  MRI of the brain is often performed in patients with PCS to evaluate for structural pathology because it is more sensitive than CT scan for detecting subtle intracranial abnormalities.  However, neuroimaging is often normal.



Management involves symptomatic care because most patients' condition improves within 3-6 months.  Acute interventions may include headache management (eg, amitriptyline), cognitive-behavioral therapy (for insomnia or anxiety), vestibular therapy (for balance issues), or reassurance alone (if symptom severity is mild).  Activity as tolerated should be encouraged.

Prognosis

Mild TBI (concussion)



Most patients with a mild TBI recover well within 7-14 days, although some may develop PCS.  Sustaining multiple concussions or suffering a second concussion before full recovery from the first can lead to severe, longer-lasting symptoms and may be associated with an increased risk for chronic headaches, neuropsychiatric disorders (eg, depression), and dementia.

Moderate to severe TBI



The prognoses of moderate and severe TBIs vary widely.  Some cases lead to death or brain death, whereas others result in long-term cognitive, motor, or psychologic impairments.  Poor outcomes are more likely in patients with low GCS score at presentation, advanced age, severe structural injuries (eg, large hemorrhage), hypoxia, elevated ICP, and history of coagulopathy.

Prevention



Prevention strategies for avoiding TBIs include proper helmet use during high-risk activities (eg, biking, skateboarding, playing contact sports), consistent use of seatbelts in motor vehicles, and fall-prevention strategies (eg, physical therapy, assistive devices) in the elderly or individuals with disabilities.

Summary



Traumatic brain injury represents a spectrum of conditions with varied clinical implications.  Mild TBI (concussion) is a minor disruption in neurocognitive function without structural abnormalities and is characterized by headache, disorientation, and cognitive/emotional changes.  It is managed with physical and cognitive rest with a gradual return to activity.  Moderate to severe TBIs can lead to significant neurologic symptoms, irreversible neurocognitive deficits, and death.  Management typically involves neurosurgical consultation and intensive care aimed at minimizing intracranial hemorrhage, intracranial pressure, and neuronal injury.
